content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I accept this contribution because I think it will be a great addition to the already existing clash of code problems and it is also really fun and satisfying to solve.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I accept this contribution because I think it will be a great addition to the already existing clash of code problems and it is also really fun and satisfying to solve.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: J'accepte cette contribution parce que , c'est ce qu'on a l'habitude de voir dans clash of code.

This is quite a frustrating problem to solve in python.
* Using  np.sqrt() instead of math.sqrt() or **.5 makes it fall short on the efficiency test
* replacing  that "answer*=2/f" by "answer = answer*2/f" in your solution is enough to have the last one or two digits wrong after test 4
For me it's too narrow of a solution, a lot of people with entry to medium level would get stuck at these steps and thus not validating despite having a technically correct solution. Frustrating.

Hi, nice problem but :
* Using a f32 or f64 do not give the same decimals (tested in Rust), this could be very frustrating when debugging.
* There is a constraints 1 ≤ N ≤ 100 but  you have a test case with 10000000
Like to discover new way to find pi, that's a great problem that implements 2 recursives computations
I hope you received enough feedback from the community to improve your contribution. Once you have made the necessary updates, publish your contribution!
like

The formula or the tests are wrong. The current tests pass with this S:
S1 = 2 * (2 / f1)
S2 = 2 * (2 / f1) * (2 / f2)
S3 = 2 * (2 / f1) * (2 / f2) * (2 / f3)
etc.

With the formula for the sequence in the statement some tests (Test 4, then Validator 5 and after that all) fail.


Edit:
If this calculates the value of pi, then it looks like the formula is correct. At least according to this https://www.piday.org/million/ :
Up to 16 decimals the value of pi is 3.1415926535897932, and the test expects 3.141592653589797, but using the formula in the statement gives 3.141592653589794, which is closer.


Edit2:
This comes from the precision of double. In ideal mathematics these parentheses do not matter, I think.

Very nice in speed-mode as well as short-mode.
I like the plot twist that the sequence converge toward π :-)
The statement is very clear and output a 15 decimal float number is very original, as it is always string/integer.

n = int(input())
fi = 2**.5
si = 2 * 2 / fi
for _ in range(n - 1):
    fi = (2 + fi)**.5
    si *= 2 / fi
print(f"{si:.15f}")
i had a problem with the last test , i have used the recursive representation for s and f
Nice!  it has two layers of sequence with S and f. Consider giving just the mathematical formula only? the user to figure how to produce S, f?

test4 fail !
15 digit ( round || floor || ceil ) ?

This would be a very good "fastest" clash of code. I was able to solve in around 3 minutes, due to over complicating it. It was very fun, and requires only a single while loop that self decrements. Also understanding how to produce 15 digit floats.

Going through, the only problem I see, is that at 15 decimals, You can't go past 26 and get a different answer. So you could hard code "if n > 25" and always get the right answer 

I didn't thoroughly test, it may be >26 or >25

Also since there's only 26 possible answers, it would be VERY easy to hard code this for massive optimization.

Very easy one, it's just need implementing the described algorithm, and difficulty is more in knowing how to display 15 digit and using double vs float , but for those who are wondering how to compute Pi it's nice to discover the math formula ;-)

I guess that level 2 of the puzzle would be to be able to provide more digits .... but that's really  more complex.

I think there is an error in statement: all "4" should be replaced with "2". Maybe something bad happened when rewriting mathematical formulas to plain text.

Consider defining S2 as "S1 * something", S3 as "S2 * something" etc. Too many parentheses may damage your health :-)

I tried in C. Output should be 20 decimals, but precision of "double" is about 15 decimal digits only. So I used "long double" but get "incorrect" results ... Please reduce precision of result, this is really misleading for me. Also, this can cause problems in some other languages (I think).
thanks! fixed to 15
thanks, simplified and fixed :)

yes first version did not specify the sequence f, but it was really difficult to read since we cannot write mathematical symbol here

It's ok to be easy :)
Right, but the user will not see the answer from the validators (e.g. n=3, n=5...)
i tried but unreadable  :D too many parenthesis...

last test case removed :)
how can the f32 / f64  issue be fixed?
does lower decimal requirements make it easier?

I agree. But you could program (which isn't really ideal) 
If n=1:
    Print("3.xxxx")
elif n=2:
    Print("3.xxxx")
And so on. 
I think however this is a perfect and I mean perfect "fastest clash of code" 
It really is fun. But not a very long challenge. 
It would be a bit better if you had the formula name and people had to look it up. Albeit if it's universal. I really enjoyed this one and I hope you keep it up. I'm just giving my 2 cents which isn't much honestly.

Sorry I don't get how would they get the answer from n=3 without computing it?

Actually it comes from the Viete's series https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vi%C3%A8te%27s_formula but I did not mention it because the solution is online :)
yes for  n>26, can be hard coded. Not sure I can improve that
My point is there are only 26 options. The formula is easier than hard coding. But they could put "if n > 26:n=26" or 27. Whatever the highest option is.
Some languages struggle with longer digits. But 15 isn't long enough for any digits above 26
